text.p: These are the leading stories in the Sarajevo press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Members of Bosnia's collective presidency urges formation of central bank as defined by Dayton peace agreement. New currency is likely to be called Bosnian mark, pegged to value of German mark, says Kasim Omicevic, governor of Bosnia's National Bank.
- A poll shows that 84 percent support the Moslem chairman of presidency, Alija Izetbegovic, in creating an advisory council to help him arrive at key decisions.
- State media board for upcoming visit of Pope John Paul II has issued 956 press accreditations for local and international journalists. Bosnian television will provide live coverage.
- John Kornblum, U.S. special envoy to Bosnia, will travel to Sarajevo for a farewell visit next week. He will be replaced by Robert Gilbard, U.S. embassy says.

- Bosnian authorities and leading Moslem party SDA will support only an integral and united Bosnia, Ejup Ganic, vice-president of Moslem-Croat federation says. All reports in the media alleging that leaders may be considering a division of Bosnia are mere speculation.

- Sarajevo will not select a mayor this week as promised. The Moslem party SDA demands that political problems in Sarajevo and the southern town of Mostar should be resolved at the same time. Leading Croat party HDZ disagrees.
- Bosnian army will hold military parade on occasion of its fifth anniversary on April 15.
- Japanese government approved $9 million for development of public transport in Sarajevo.

- Hunt for two indicted war ciminals Radovan Karadzic and Ratko Mladic will start by the end of May, diplomatic sources say. Under the plan Radovan Karadzic will be killed and Bosnian Serb army general Ratko Maldic will be extradited to the U.N. war crimes tribunal in the Hague.
